Title: "Querying Azure Search Index Using Search Documents API in PowerShell"
Text:
C:\Users\adamh\Downloads\azure-search.pdfIndexResult)",    "value":  [                {                    "key":  "1",                    "status":  true,                    "errorMessage":  null,                    "statusCode":  201                },                {                    "key":  "2",                    "status":  true,                    "errorMessage":  null,                    "statusCode":  201                },                {This step shows you how to query an index using the Search Documents API.
Be sure to use single quotes on search $urls. Query strings include $ characters, and youcan omit having to escape them if the entire string is enclosed in single quotes.1. Set the endpoint to the hotels-quickstart docs collection and add a searchparameter to pass in a query string.
This string executes an empty search (search=*), returning an unranked list (searchscore = 1.0) of arbitrary documents. By default, Azure AI Search returns 50 matchesat a time. As structured, this query returns an entire document structure andvalues. Add $count=true to get a count of all documents in the results.
PowerShell2. Run the command to send the $url to the service.PowerShellResults should look similar to the following output.                    "key":  "3",                    "status":  true,                    "errorMessage":  null,                    "statusCode":  201                },                {                    "key":  "4",                    "status":  true,                    "errorMessage":  null,                    "statusCode":  201                }            ]}3 - Search an index$url = 'https://<YOUR-SEARCH-SERVICE>.search. windows.net/indexes/hotels-quickstart/docs?api-version=2020-06-30&search=*&$count=true'Invoke-RestMethod -Uri $url -Headers $headers | ConvertTo-JsonTry a few other query examples to get a feel for the syntax.
